title: Ted Kaczynski's Low-Tech Lifestyle
notes: An interesting look at what it's like to be a recluse in nature, subsisting on the land.  A lot of what he wrote rings true: evil jet planes flying overhead are in fact ruining the beautiful natural world.  In an alternate universe, Dr. Kaczynski becomes a lawyer, sues the airline industry, and amasses preserved land in Montana that becomes Kazcynski National Park after his death.  Pack it in, pack it out, and no more than 1 person per square mile at any given time; these rules are strictly enforced.

Your World Is Burning. Here's What You Can Actually Do About It.
notes: Real power lives in the granular. It’s in the newsletter you publish about local issues nobody else covers. It’s in the mutual aid network you start with three neighbors that grows to thirty. It’s in the skill-sharing workshops you organize in your garage. It’s in the community garden you plant in the abandoned lot. It’s in the tech support hours you offer seniors at the local library. It’s in the tools and knowledge you share without waiting for permission or platforms. Small actions, multiplied by consistency, backed by a commitment to a specific place and specific people.
